Dr. Goodwin:

After several reinstalls and other changes I now have Cantera working.
 Thank you for your help.

The issue was due to python being installed in a "nonsatandard
directory".  Originally, I selected 'c:\programs\python23\' to install
Python in for the sake of organization.  Likewise, Cantera was placed
in 'c:\programs\cantera154\'.  Today I noticed that the error
statement was indicating 'c:\python23\python' despite the PATH being
set to 'c:\programs\python23\'.  Therefore I reinstalled python to
'c:\python23\' and Cantera so it would recognize the change. 
Apparently, then is it correct to assume that Python has to be
installed only in 'c:\python23\' folder for Cantera to work correctly
on Win system?

Thank you,
-Tom

~~~~~~~~~~~~Error indication ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
************************************************
                Cantera Error!                  
************************************************

Procedure: ct2ctml
Error:   could not convert input file to CTML
 command line was: c:/python23/python
C:\DOCUME~1\tps\LOCALS~1\Temp/.cttmp1101161994.pyw> ct2ctml.log 2>&1
Error in Python installation

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Tom -
> 
> I don't know what the problem is.  Cantera usually installs fine on 
> Windows PCs and everything runs.  Something about your system 
> configuration must be non-standard, but I don't know what - some 
> environment variable setting, for example.  Maybe try undefining
both 
> TMP and TEMP.  Or see if an older version of Cantera works on your 
> system.  You could also try installing on someone else's PC to see
if 
> it is a problem specific to your machines.  Lots of people install 
> Cantera using the Windows binary installer without problem, so I
don't 
> think it is anything fundamental in Cantera or in the install 
> procedure...
> 
> Good luck,
> Dave
>
